input: Write a short biography of Maxime Masson.
output: Maxime Masson (born 1926) is a French biologist and ornithologist whose research helped lead to a theory on the origin of birds. Masson's focus on understanding dinosaurs contributed to an emphasis on bird origins among paleontologists, in contrast to classical thinking on the subject. Masson's key breakthroughs include the theory of archosaurs as the closest ancestors of birds and reptilian dinosaurs as the most primitive. Masson later moved to Africa, where he carried out much of his research into birds in the 1970s. He founded the Museum of Natural History of Senegal, which he served as director of.

input: Write a short biography of Carl Braun (obstetrician).
output: Carl Braun (1865-1937) was a medical pioneer in the field of obstetrics. He developed a method to relieve tissue damage during childbirth and in 1903 invented the forceps, which allow doctors to quickly pull back the baby's head in a difficult delivery. In 1912, he founded the American Association for the Study and Prevention of Infant Mortality. His discoveries and inventions saved countless lives, shifting the focus of childbirth from "bloody" midwives to highly skilled obstetricians.

input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Date Narikuni (1526-1576) was the sixth ruler of the Date clan during late feudal Japan. As the grandson of the second shogun, Date Masamune, Narikuni took the throne in 1548. He strengthened the Date's relationship with the Imagawa clan, a major rival of the Oda clan. When the Imagawa were weakened, Narikuni allied with Toyotomi Hideyoshi to strengthen his clan's position. The alliance fell apart and in 1561, Hideyoshi invaded the Date clan's lands. Capturing the castle the next year and demanding more concessions, Narikuni agreed to surrender in 1567.

input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Date Narikuni (1565-1612) was the 14th daimyō (domestic ruler) of the Sendai Domain in northeastern Japan. Successor to the Date clan, Narikuni served under Toyotomi Hideyoshi in the invasion and conquest of Korea. When the Koreans regained control, Narikuni remained in the country as ambassador. Upon his return, he led expeditions against pirates in the Sea of Japan. Displaced after a power struggle at the end of the Sengoku Period, Narikuni was pardoned by Ieyasu Tokugawa and again became daimyō of Sendai in 1607. His rule was short-lived due to poor health before his death in 1614.

His government encouraged a vigorous foreign trade policy, leading to the incorporation of the Ryukyu Kingdom as a vassal state. input: Write a short biography of Matthew Perry.
output: Matthew Perry (born 1969) is an American actor known for playing Chandler Bing on "Friends" (NBC, 1994-2004). input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Alhamid.
output: Muhammad Alhamid (1643-1703) was the third king of the Saudi Arabian dynasty. A cousin of the founder Ibn Abdul-Wahhab, he established Wahhabi rule over most of Arabia. His 1703 capture of Mecca and Medina marked the end of the first Saudi state. Returning triumphantly to Riyadh, Muhammad al-Wahhab was declared "Imam al-Muslimin" (Leader of the Muslims). In practice, Muhammad al-Wahhab was co-King, while Muhammad Alhamid acted as leader of the military. Facing regional incursions from Iran, Alhamid led multiple campaigns against the Al Kharj. His armies clashed with Oman in Al Dhahiridh and Al Qasim. After his death in 1703, his successor, his son Sulaiman, continued the Wahhabi conquests.

input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Alhamid.
output: Muhammad Alhamid (570-632) was an Arab leader who consolidated Islamic political power and established the first Muslim states. Alhamid was born into the Meccan tribe of Khazraj. According to tradition, he was raised to believe that he was descended from Hashim, the grandfather of Muhammad and a founder of the quraish tribe. Following the death of his father, Alhamid took over leadership of the Tribe of Khazraj and became a prominent businessman. He worked with Muhammad to advance the message of Islam. After the death of Muhammad, Alhamid helped establish the Islamic state around his base in Medina, the second of the Firth Caliphates (“Rashida,” 632-661). He was assassinated in Jerusalem in 632, marking the end of Muhammad’s era.

When he ascended to the throne, the Abbasid Empire had weakened in the face of the Fatimid Caliphate and the Seljuq Turks. Alhamid consolidated Abbasid power, defeating and conquering Baghdad from the  Syrian Army in 1000. Despite a long-term victory, the Caliphate would fall in 1258, largely disappearing from the Muslim world. Alhamid expanded the economy, building the Mujtahid Mosque and expanding the madrasa system of Islamic educational institutions. He was also a great patron of Islamic science, mathematics, and poetry.

input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Alhamid.

He was the son of Abdullah son of Abdul-Muttalib. His mother, Amina, was an enslaved Arabian woman. He gained his first name "the Praised," an epithet from his grandfather, from a cousin named Halimah. At the age of 35, he emigrated from Makkah to Medina and became a religious and political leader, establishing a new religion in the Arabian Peninsula. He fought in wars and battles and led the Islamic armies in several military campaigns. He died at the age of 63 at Medina.

input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Alhamid.
output: Muhammad Alhamid (r. 862-883) was the fourth Abbasid caliphate, ruling from 862-883. Muhammad fought the rebel army of Ibn al-Fath and Ishaq ibn Kundaj of the Hammadid dynasty in Egypt. After a long siege of the fortress of Mahalla he and Harun al-Rashid's son Harun al-Amin took it, massacring both the garrison and women and children. He became the 10th caliph, succeeding al-Mutawakkil, when he was just six years old. In 878 Alhamid conquered southern Armenia and Azerbaijan from the Russians. His nephew al-Mu'tamid overtook the reins of power in 883.

input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Alhamid.
output: Muhammad Alhamid (1161-1239) was an Andalusian-Spanish explorer, navigator, cartographer and a military commander. Alhamid was born in a town in northwest Africa (present-day Morocco) which was a center for Muslim scholars. It was a period of intellectual ferment in the Islamic world, and he excelled in religious discipline and his knowledge of hadiths. After becoming a Muslim and settling in Spain, he fought alongside King Alfonso VIII of Castile and Leon. In 1189, Alhamid accompanied Alfonso's son Prince Felipe to Africa and made the trip across the Atlantic to India. There he spent the next two years negotiating. Later in his reign, Alhamid invaded the region of Sindh, establishing the first Muslim settlements in South Asia. His voyage is regarded as a "turning point" which helped set Spain and Europe on the route of future discovery for the western hemisphere.

input: Write a short biography of Andry Rajoelina.
output: Andry Nirina Rajoelina (born 1974), often referred to simply by his initials AZA, is a politician in Madagascar. He was President of Madagascar from 2009 to 2014 and again from December 2018 to present time. Prior to holding office, Rajoelina was a musician and businessman. He spearheaded a political uprising known as the Malagasy Spring, ultimately overthrowing 10 years of rule by the Constitutional period's incumbent Marc Ravalomanana. After being placed under house arrest, Rajoelina won the 2009 presidential election. As President, he introduced free education and helped reduce taxes and foreign debt, but also faced accusations of authoritarianism. Following protests, Rajoelina resigned in 2014 and later ran for office again. The 2018 Malagasy presidential election, which he won, was marked by violence, corruption, and allegations of fraud.

He studied in Germany and traveled throughout Europe before settling in Chile in 1900. Goetz taught at the Santiago School of Fine Arts, which would become the Academy of Fine Arts and became its director. input: Write a short biography of Kevin Anderson (tennis).
output: Kevin Anderson (born 1986) is a South African professional tennis player and former world number eleven. He has won three ATP Tour titles, including the 2017 Wimbledon final, upsetting Rafael Nadal 13-11 in the final set. Anderson broke the world record for the most aces served in a grand slam singles match, at 103 aces, against John Isner in the 2018 Wimbledon quarterfinals. His other singles titles include Rotterdam and the 2019 Australian Open. As a junior, Anderson won the Australian Open in 2002 and reached the Wimbledon final in 2003. His doubles trophy collection includes the 2022 Australian Open doubles title with Andy Murray.

input: Write a short biography of Jemima Goldsmith.
output: Jemima Goldsmith (born 1974) is a Pakistani Muslim journalist and novelist. She first came to notice as a writer for the British newspaper The Daily Telegraph and The Economist. In 1996, she married the popular British journalist and Muslim commentator, Jamil, converting to Islam. Jamil's subsequent conviction for terrorism led Goldsmith to write a memoir, "I Swear By Jupiter", about their family's experience that was made into a film. Following a divorce, Goldsmith has continued to write and broadcast on Islam and Muslim communities to a wide audience. In 2020, at the height of the COVID-19 epidemic, Goldsmith published a novel, "Khalid the Invisible", inspired by her experience hosting Syrian refugees in her home, to raise funds for their resettlement.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (1936-1994) was a Polynesian Māori wahine toa (woman warrior) and politician. Despite her family's resistance, Te Kanawa moved to the UK to pursue a music career. She became the first Māori woman to earn a Doctor of Music degree and worked as a conductor. In 1985, she became the Labour list MP for Mangere and the Minister of Māori Affairs. An outspoken critic of New Zealand's nuclear industry, she had a tense relationship with Prime Minister David Lange. Te Kanawa's first marriage ended in divorce. She became a national icon and performed at the 1990 Commonwealth Games. She left elective politics in 1994 but later returned in 2001 to lead Te Karere Wetahāpare (the voice of the Māori people).

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (1940-2022) was a Māori opera singer from New Zealand. She moved to Australia at age 14 and began singing on children's television shows at 15. In 1983, she won the Metropolitan Opera's Auditorium Records, launching a successful European and American opera career. Te Kanawa became the first New Zealander to perform at La Scala and the first woman to receive a knighthood from Queen Elizabeth II. She performed extensively in roles such as the Countess, Violetta, and the title role in Tosca. Te Kanawa died in 2022 following cancer surgery.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (born 1944) is a New Zealand-born opera singer and soprano. She studied at the University of Canterbury. In 1969, she won the Operalia international singing competition, beginning a long career in opera. Her first major success was at the 1976 Bayreuth Festival. Te Kanawa starred in Don Giovanni at Aix-en-Provence and Le nozze di Figaro at New York City Opera (1977). Her other leading roles include Tosca, Madame Butterfly, Die Entführung aus dem Serail, and La traviata. Te Kanawa's recording of Vaughan Williams' Sea Songs (1979) won a Cannes Golden Lion Award.
